head.title: Rookie Propels Liberty to No. 2 Seeding

hedline.hl1: Rookie Propels Liberty to No. 2 Seeding
hedline.hl2: Liberty's Top Draft Pick Gets It Done

abstract.p: New York Liberty defeats Washington Mystics, 79-75 (M)

block.p: The smile on Shameka Christon's face said it all yesterday.
Christon, a relatively unknown player from the University of Arkansas, showed the 15,698 fans at Madison Square Garden why the Liberty had made her the team's No. 1 draft pick.
Shameka Christon scored a career-high 18 points to help the Liberty clinch the No. 2 playoff seeding in the Eastern Conference.
The smile on Shameka Christon's face said it all yesterday.
Christon, a relatively unknown player from the University of Arkansas, showed the 15,698 fans at Madison Square Garden why the Liberty had made her the team's No. 1 draft pick.

With her mentor, forward Crystal Robinson, on the bench for most of the second half with a sprained right big toe, Christon scored a career-high 18 points to help the Liberty clinch the No. 2 playoff seeding in the Eastern Conference and homecourt advantage in the first round with a 79-75 victory over the Washington Mystics.
Having vacated Madison Square Garden because of the Republican National Convention, the Liberty played its first game there after going 5-1 at Radio City Music Hall.
The Liberty will open the two-of-three-game series against the Detroit Shock, the defending champion, in Auburn Hills, Mich., on Friday. Game 2 will be Sunday at the Garden.
Game 3, if necessary, will be played Tuesday at the Garden.
The loss was the Mystics' first in four games against the Liberty this season and dropped them to the fourth seeding.
Christon, who wears No. 20, was nearly upstaged by another No. 20, Alana Beard, the player Christon affectionately refers to as her high school nemesis.
Beard, the Mystics' No. 1 draft pick and the former Duke star, scored 21 of her game-high 23 points in the second half.
Beard scored 19 of the Mystics' first 21 points after intermission.

It was a battle between teams that have faced adversity: the Liberty fired Coach Richie Adubato at the beginning of July, and the Mystics lost the All-Star forward Chamique Holdsclaw to an undisclosed illness.
The game was close down the stretch, but Becky Hammon hit a 3-pointer with 35 seconds left and added a foul shot with 26 seconds remaining.
Hammon finished with 18 points, Elena Baranova had 16 points and Bethany Donaphin added 10.
After the game, Robinson beamed with pride at Christon's big game.
''My protégé,'' she said, nodding in Christon's direction. ''If I had as much athletic ability like Shameka. Wow. She is going to be great.''

Christon, who has averaged 4.8 points and 16 minutes a game this season, saved her best game for last. Throughout the season, Christon, a 6-foot-1 forward, had shown only flashes of the scoring ability that had propelled her to second on the Arkansas career list with 1,951 points. ''Blaze always told me, 'Shameka this is a simple game,''' Christon said, referring to Carol Blazejowski, the senior vice president and general manager for the Liberty.

''I think I put too much pressure on myself. Thinking I had to do the same thing I did at Arkansas, being the biggest scorer. My teammates and coaches told me to have that confidence and to play within myself. Today I was able to do that.''
PRO BASKETBALL
